prompt.p: A 25-year-old woman complains of a gradual increase in a painless neck swelling. The history reveals that she has felt warm and had some weight loss. Inspection of her neck is shown in the figure.
What features of this swelling would you expect to elicit on clinical examination?
Douglas et al, Macleod's Clinical Examination , 12 th edn.

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Elevation of swelling on tongue protrusion
The swelling is pulsatile on palpation

modalFeedback.p: Option A is Correct. This patient has a thyroid nodule.
[Fig. reproduced from Douglas et al, Macleod's Clinical Examination , 12 th edn., 2009, with permission from Elsevier. Fig. 5.3(C) Goitre (Uninodular – toxic nodule)]
Option B is Incorrect. This occurs with a thyroglossal cyst due to its embryological connection to the foramen caecum of the tongue. It also tends to be a midline swelling.
Option C is Incorrect. A brachial cyst may have a sinus and may be tender if infected. The patient would not display heat intolerance.
Option D is Incorrect. This occurs with a pharyngeal pouch. It is more prevalent in men and the elderly. The patient's history does not fit this diagnosis.
Option E is Incorrect. A carotid swelling will be pulsatile (a glomus tumour).
